column1: List of All CHI 2013 SIG Meetings (Juried) Submissions

column3: Title
column9: Author list
column140: Keywords
column141: Abstract

column3: Tips&Tricks for a Better Usability Test: Improving Problem Severity Ratings
column9: Chancey Wilson, Rolf Molich, Jennifer (Jen) McGinn, Nigel Bevan
column140: Usability Testing and Evaluation; Usability Research
column141: In this SIG experienced usability practitioners will discuss what can be done to achieve more consistent ratings of the severity of usability problems discovered in usability evaluations. The CUE-9 study, conducted in 2011 with 35 professional usability testers working independently, demonstrated that problem severity ratings are highly unreliable. While there was a reasonable level of rater agreement in problem identification, the severity assigned to those problems varied wildly from "not a problem" to "devastating".

column3: SIG NIME: Music, Technology, and Human-Computer Interaction
column9: Frederic Bevilacqua, Sidney Fels, Alexander Jensenius, Michael Lyons, Norbert Schnell, Atau Tanaka
column52: College of Image Arts and Sciences
column140: Input and Interaction Technologies; Auditory I/O and Sound in the UI; Interaction Design; Multi-modal interfaces
column141: This SIG intends to investigate the ongoing dialogue between music technology and the field of human-computer interaction. Our specific aims are to consider major findings of  musical interface research over recent years and discuss how these might best be conveyed to CHI researchers interested but not yet active in this area, as well as to consider how to stimulate future collaborations between music technology and CHI research communities.

column3: A new Perspectives for the Games and Entertainment Community
column9: Regina Bernhaupt, Katherine Isbister
column14: IRIT, University Paul Sabatier, Toulouse III
column140: Entertainment
column141: Games and Entertainment have become an important area for researchers in Human-Computer Interaction. The games and entertainment community has been growing continuously in the past three years. During CHI 2012 a two days workshop on Games User Research was held, and the growing number of game-oriented submissions show the importance of the field. In 2013 the successful Student Games Competition is continued and we plan for engaging game content during CHI 2013. The games and entertainment community is the only community that got the agreement of the Conference Management Committee of SIGCHI to extend the existence beyond the initial three years. The Games and Entertainment Community is thus extended for the years 2014 and following. It is of immense importance for the community to have a possibility to discuss new perspectives for the Games and Entertainment Community in a SIG.

column3: Research-Practice Interaction: Building Bridges, Closing the Gap
column9: Elizabeth Buie, Clare Hooper, Aaron Houssian
column140: User Experience Design / Experience Design
column141: Previous work in the CHI community has identified and explored gaps between theory and practice in HCI research [2]. The recently formed SIGCHI Community on Research-Practice Interaction aims to help bridge the gap between research and practice, by for example supporting practitioner-friendly dissemination of results, and serving as a conduit for feedback from practitioners to researchers. This SIG is an opportunity for interested CHI attendees to meet members of the SIGCHI RPI community, and engage in discussions on RPI issues including the CHI format, dissemination of results, and supporting practice-based research.

column3: Designing Interactive Secure System: CHI 2013 Special Interest Group
column9: Shamal Faily, Lizzie Coles-Kemp, Paul Dunphy, Mike Just, Yoko Akama, Alexander De Luca
column140: Security; Design Methods (Design Rationale, Claims Analysis, Scenarios, Storyboards); Software Engineering Methods and Processes - Mathematical/Formal; User-Centered Design / Human-Centered Design
column141: Despite a growing interest in the design and engineering of interactive secure systems, there is also a noticeable amount of fragmentation.  This has led to a lack of awareness about what research is currently being carried out, and misunderstandings about how different fields can contribute to the design of usable and secure systems.  By drawing interested members of the CHI community from design, user experience, engineering, and HCI Security, this SIG will take the first steps towards creating a research agenda for interactive secure system design.  In the SIG, we will summarise recent initatives to develop a research programme in interactive secure system design, network members of the CHI community with an interest in this research area, and initiate a roadmap towards addressing identified research challenges and building an interactive secure system design community.

column3: Visions and Visioning in CHI
column9: Aaron Quigley, Alan Dix, Wendy Mackay, Hiroshi Ishii, Jürgen Steimle
column140: Interaction Design; Social and Legal issues
column141: There are many visions that touch on the future of human computer interaction from a trans-human future to a post-technological UI. However visions related to the progress of technology are not new. Creative and insightful visionaries from Denis Diderot to Vannerar Bush have been postulating visions of possible futures or technology for centuries. Some idealised views end up discredited with advances in knowledge, while others now appear remarkably prescient. The question is, do visions and the process of creating them have a place in CHI, or are they simply flights of fancy? \  \ This SIG meeting provides a forum for visionaries; researchers and practitioners looking to consider the place and importance of visions within CHI. Can visions, the process of visioning and forming new visions help us refine, advance or develop new research or forms of interaction. And if visions are important to us, then are they part of the regular academic process? If so, should CHI provide venues for publishing new visions?

column3: Current Issues in Assessing and Improving Information Usability
column9: Stephanie Rosenbaum, Judith Ramey
column140: User Experience Design / Experience Design; Information Architecture; Interaction Design; User-Centered Design / Human-Centered Design
column141: The usability of information is vital to successful websites, products, and services. Managers and developers often recognize the role of information or content in overall product usability, but miss opportunities to improve information usability as part of the product-development effort. This meeting is an annual forum on human factors of information design, in which we discuss issues selected by the group from the facilitators’ list of topics, augmented by attendees’ suggestions.

column3: Automotive User Interface Research Moves into Fast Lane
column9: Susanne Boll, Andrew L. Kun, Peter Fröhlich
column140: User-Centered Design / Human-Centered Design; Augmented Reality and Tangible UI; Context-Aware Computing; Emotion and Affective User Interface; Handheld Devices and Mobile Computing; Input and Interaction Technologies; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Entertainment; Universal (or Disability)  Access; Interaction Design; User and Cognitive models; Usability Testing and Evaluation; User Studies; Usability Research; User Interface Design; Multi-modal interfaces
column141: Cars have become complex interactive systems. Mechanical controls and electrical systems are transformed to the digital realm. It is common that drivers operate a vehicle and, at the same time, interact with a variety of devices and applications. Texting while driving, looking up an address for the navigation system, and taking a phone call are just some common examples that add value for the driver, but also increase the risk of driving. Novel interaction technologies create many opportunities for designing useful and attractive in-car user interfaces. With technologies that assist the user in driving, such as assistive cruise control and lane keeping, the user interface is essential to the way people perceive the driving experience. New means for user interface development and interaction design are required as many other conditions have an influence on the design space for automotive user interfaces. In comparison to other domains, a trial and error approach while the product is already in the market is not acceptable as the cost of failure may be fatal. User interface design in the automotive domain is relevant across many areas ranging from primary driving control, to assisted functions, to navigation, information services, entertainment and games and the communication with the environment and other cars.

column3: CHI 2013 Human Work Interaction Design (HWID) SIG: Past History and Future Challenges
column9: Torkil Clemmensen, Pedro Campos, Dinesh Katre, Jose Abdelnour-Nocera, Arminda Lopes, Rikke Orngreen, Dr. Shailey Minocha
column79: DPU - the danish scool of education, aarhus university
column140: Interaction Design; Context-Aware Computing; Computer Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW); Emotion and Affective User Interface; Home; Office and Workplace; Design Methods (Design Rationale, Claims Analysis, Scenarios, Storyboards); Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Ethnography; Industrial Design; Organizational Culture / Organizational Planning; User Studies; User-Centered Design / Human-Centered Design; Product Design; Usability Research; User Experience Design / Experience Design
column141: In this SIG we aim to introduce the IFIP 13.6 Human Work Interaction Design (HWID) approach to the CHI audience. The HWID working group aims at establishing relationships between extensive empirical work-domain studies and HCI design. We invite participants from industry and academia with an interest on empirical work analysis, HCI, interaction design and usability and user experience in work situations and at the workplace. This SIG is a vital step towards creating a CHI2014 workshop on the topic.

column3: HCI with Sports
column9: Florian Mueller, Rohit Khot, Alan Chatham, Sebastiaan Pijnappel, Cagdas "Chad" Toprak, Joe Marshall
column140: Interaction Design; Context-Aware Computing; Handheld Devices and Mobile Computing; Input and Interaction Technologies; Product Design; User Experience Design / Experience Design; Tactile & Haptic UIs; Multi-modal interfaces
column141: Recent advances in cheap sensor technology has made technology support for sports and physical exercise increasingly commonplace, which is evident from the growing popularity of heart rate monitors and GPS sports watches. This rise of technology to support sports activities raises many interaction issues, such as how to interact with these devices while moving and physically exerting. This special interest group brings together industry practitioners and researchers who are interested in designing and understanding human-computer interaction where the human is being physically active, engaging in exertion activities. Fitting with the theme, this special interest group will be “run” while running: participants will be invited to a jog together during which we will discuss technology interaction that is specific to being physically active while being physically active ourselves.

column3: SIG: NVI (Non-Visual Interaction)
column9: Anke Brock, Slim Kammoun, Hugo Nicolau, Tiago Guerreiro, Shaun Kane, Christophe Jouffrais
column140: Input and Interaction Technologies; Auditory I/O and Sound in the UI; Universal (or Disability)  Access; Tactile & Haptic UIs
column141: In recent years there has been a surge in the development of non-visual interaction techniques targeting two application areas: making content accessible to visually impaired people, and supporting minimal attention user interfaces for on-the-go mobile users. This SIG aims to bring together the community of researchers exploring non-visual interaction techniques. The SIG will bring members of this burgeoning community together in a lively discussion and brainstorming session. Attendees will work to identify and report current and future research challenges, and to identify future directions of this research area.

column3: HCI for Peace Ideathon
column9: Juan Pablo Hourcade, Lisa Nathan, Panayiotis Zaphiris, Massimo Zancanaro, Evangelos Kapros, John Thomas, Daniela Busse
column66: Trinity College, The University of Dublin
column140: Social and Legal issues; Handheld Devices and Mobile Computing; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Interaction Design; Internationalization / Localization; Product Design; User Experience Design / Experience Design; User Interface Design
column141: Computers are increasingly mediating the way people make decisions, including those that can have an effect on conflict and peace. In addition, recent research provides empirical data on the factors that affect the likelihood of armed conflict. These conditions provide an unprecedented opportunity to the human-computer interaction community to play a role in preventing, de-escalating, and recovering from conflicts. This SIG will be the first opportunity for CHI attendees to meet during the main part of the conference, share their ideas, and provide concrete ways to move forward with this line of research

column3: UrbanIXD :: Designing Human Interactions In The Networked City
column9: Michael Smyth, Ingi Helgason, Martin Brynskov, Ivica Mitrovic, Gianluca Zaffiro
column140: Interaction Design; Ubiquitous Computing / Smart Environments; Multidisciplinary Design / Interdisciplinary Design; User-Centered Design / Human-Centered Design
column141: Interaction Design, in an urban context, is an increasingly important field of research. City populations are currently in a state of rapid flux. Conurbations are fast becoming a hybrid of the physical environment and the digital datasphere. How we, as physical beings, will connect with, interpret and adapt this increasing dataflow residing in our cities is already becoming a significant research question. The SIG organisers will frame the discussion through a human–centred view of the concerns, experiences and behaviours that may occur in cities of the future. By adopting an approach of Thinking and Doing it is hoped that the SIG will act as a catalyst for community building.

column3: Science vs. Science: the Complexities of Interdisciplinary Research
column9: Clare Hooper, David Millard, Jill Fantauzzacoffin, Joseph 'Jofish' Kaye
column39: Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, Georgia, United States
column140: Multidisciplinary Design / Interdisciplinary Design; Analysis Methods (e.g. Task/Interaction Modeling); User-Centered Design / Human-Centered Design
column141: Human-Computer Interaction and Web Science are radically interdisciplinary fields, but what does this mean in practical terms? Undertaking research (and writing papers) that encompass multiple disciplinary perspectives and methods is a serious challenge and it is difficult to maintain conferences that fairly review and host contributions from multiple disciplines. \  \ The colocation of the ACM WebSci conference with CHI in Paris, offers an unusual opportunity to bring these two communities together. Previous discussions have considered how to conduct interdisciplinary work that bridges HCI/WebSci with specific areas. Our objective is to provide a space for interested researchers from both communities to share their views and approaches to tackling the tensions and complexities associated with interdisciplinary work, whatever fields are being bridged.

column3: The Role of Engineering Work in CHI
column9: Philippe Palanque, Fabio Paternò, Jeffrey Nichols, Nuno Nunes, Brad Myers
column52: University of Madeira, Funchal, Madeira, Portugal
column140: Software architecture and engineering; Development Tools / Toolkits / Programming Environments; Ubiquitous Computing / Smart Environments; Software Engineering Methods and Processes - Mathematical/Formal
column141: The Engineering Community faces a number of issues around its role in the larger CHI community and its contribution to SIGCHI-sponsored conferences. This SIG is its forum to report progress on key issues for 2013, identify objectives for 2014, and develop plans to address them.

column3: Speak Your Mind with Computational Support: How to Communicate Thoughts Efficiently?
column9: Marius Brade, Horst Werner, Markus Latzina, Rainer Groh
column14: Technische Universität Dresden, Chair of Media Design
column140: User Interface Design; Visualization; User and Cognitive models; Multidisciplinary Design / Interdisciplinary Design
column141: This SIG brings together practitioners, researchers and designers who are interested in how to optimize com-puter supported tools for efficient communication of thoughts. This interdisciplinary group combines the disciplines ranging from interaction design to cognitive science, artificial intelligence, knowledge management and technologies, arts and product design.
column142: design, engineering, management, user experience, arts

column3: Promoting HCI in Small Countries
column9: David Lamas, Panayiotis Zaphiris, Georgios Christou
column13: Interaction Design Lab / Institute of Informatics
column140: Social and Legal issues; Organizational Culture / Organizational Planning; User Studies
column141: This SIG aims to further the understanding of the challenges related to the design and evaluation of digital interactive artifacts in small countries. \  \ Computing is at one of its most exciting moments, playing an essential role in supporting human activities, facilitated by the growing availability of services, devices and interaction modalities. Moreover, users were brought from the periphery to the center of an emerging and pervasive socio-technical system, with the evolution from the large-scale computing to the contemporary ubiquitous computing interaction paradigms through the successive waves of the personal, networked, collaborative, mobile, augmented and virtual reality interaction paradigms. \  \ Notwithstanding, we still design and evaluate interactive systems and technologies without fully taking into account our cognitive abilities, the ways we perceive and handle information, go about our work and life, create and maintain social relations, use our cultural context and relate to our environment. \  \ This specially true in small countries due to combination of specific cultural values with rather small market sizes, which hinders the development of localized design and evaluation methods.

column3: On Top of the User Experience Wave – How is Our Work Changing?
column9: Virpi Roto, Arnie Lund
column140: User-Centered Design / Human-Centered Design; User Studies; Product Design; User Experience Design / Experience Design
column141: The field of Human-Computer Interaction has evolved over three decades, from human factors and usability to user experience. But what has changed in practice, in the approaches and methods we use? Has anything changed other than the names of the teams within organizations? And what might be coming next? In this SIG, we discuss how the work of HCI professionals has changed over the years and explore the future of their work.

column3: Human Computer Interaction for Development (HCI4D)
column9: Ban Al-Ani, Melissa Densmore, Edward Cutrell, Rebecca Grinter, John Thomas, Andy Dearden, Matthew Kam, Anicia Peters
column53: College of Computing, Georgia Institute of Technology
column140: Computer-Mediated Communication; Computer Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW); Handheld Devices and Mobile Computing; Children; Elderly; E-Learning and Education; Health Care; Home; Office and Workplace; Universal (or Disability)  Access; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Ethnography; Interaction Design; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; Usability Testing and Evaluation; User Studies; User-Centered Design / Human-Centered Design; Usability Research; User Experience Design / Experience Design; User Interface Design; Creativity Support Tools; Sustainability
column141: We are proposing a SIG designed for Human-Computer Interaction for Development (HCI4D) Community. It is designed to foster further collaboration, dissemination of research results and findings from practitioners, as well as to promote discussion of how we can both learn from each other and from those we serve in underserved communities wherever they may be.

column3: Find Hidden Design Implications from Contextual Inquiry Data
column9: Wei Zhou, Chiao-Yu Lu, Di Meng
column140: Usability Research; Analysis Methods (e.g. Task/Interaction Modeling); Design Methods (Design Rationale, Claims Analysis, Scenarios, Storyboards); Ethnography; Experience Strategy; User Studies
column141: Contextual inquiry as a research method has gained its popularity these years among user experience practitioners. “Affinity diagram” has been commonly used to organize and analyze the field data collected. However, in many cases, it is not enough to draw our conclusions based on a few “Aha!” moments, because we see trends from the affinity diagrams. We should also consider the rich and “messy” observational data that are not obvious to form trends, and abstract hidden implications from them. But how we could accomplish it has remained as a challenge. \  \ In this SIG, we will start with two real cases from our own work, and demonstrate how we found the hidden implications from our data. Then we will explore and discuss strategies and tips from different perspectives.  \

column3: Enhancing the Research Infrastructure for Child-Computer Interaction
column9: Janet C Read, Juan Pablo Hourcade
column140: Children; E-Learning and Education
column141: The child-computer interaction community has been steadily adding research infrastructure over the past 20 years through books, the Interaction Design and Children conference, being a featured community at CHI, through an official IFIP group, and more recently through a journal. In this SIG we will discuss the next steps to further strengthen the research infrastructure in this research community with the goals of improving the quality of the research, enhancing research resources, and increasing the impact of the field in industry and education.

column3: SIG Exploring Mobile Experiences For Digital Tourism.pdf
column9: Oliver Mival, Brian O'Keefe, David Benyon, Ken Parulski
column140: User Experience Design / Experience Design; Handheld Devices and Mobile Computing; Interaction Design; Experience Strategy
column141: This SIG will explore the design, development and deployment requirements, considerations and constraints when creating mobile experiences for digital tourism. The discussion is intended to be valuable to both researchers and practitioners and we welcome both groups to share their experiences, ideas, case studies, successes and failures.

column3: Managing UX Teams
column9: Janice Rohn, Carola Thompson
column140: Business Strategy; Office and Workplace; Organizational Culture / Organizational Planning; User Experience Design / Experience Design
column141: This SIG will serve two purposes:  as a forum to share the results from the two-day CHI workshop, and also as a forum for the management community to discuss topics of interest.

column3: Mobile Design Challenges and Strategies for the Enterprise
column9: Di Meng, Dan Garrison, Brian Sarbin, Wei Zhou
column140: User Experience Design / Experience Design; Information Architecture; Home; Office and Workplace; Interaction Design; Design Planning; Experience Strategy; User-Centered Design / Human-Centered Design; Product Design; User Interface Design; Security
column141: People’s usage of mobile devices has been increasing exponentially in recent years. In response to this growing trend and to meet their users’ behavior and expectations, many consumer-oriented companies have produced compelling mobile experiences that have improved their users’ satisfaction with the company and brand. As an extreme, some startups have even been founded with a focus purely on designing and developing for mobile platforms. So why have we not seen this same proliferation and mobile focus in the enterprise application space? In this SIG, we plan to discuss and debate some of the reasons for this lagging on the enterprise side. As part of this discussion, we will explore strategies for dealing with enterprise-centric issues such as navigation/IA, large data sets, complex backend systems, security, and even considerations intrinsic to the organization such as structure and process.

column3: Digital Art: Challenging Perspectives
column9: David England, Jill Fantauzzacoffin, Thecla Schiphorst, Celine Latulipe, Linda Candy
column53: University of North Carolina at Charlotte
column140: Visual System Design / Visual Design
column141: In this SIG for the Digital Arts Community, we respond to the conference theme of changing perspectives by offering challenging perspectives. The challenge comes in a two-way exchange between Digital Art and HCI. On the one side we have the making of new and unique forms, i.e. synthesis. Whilst on the other, we have knowledge-making grounded in the human sciences and engineering, in other words, predicting and validating analysis. In this SIG session we will provoke a discussion on these contrasting challenging perspectives. How does knowledge.

column3: Changing Perspectives on Sustainability: Healthy Debate or Divisive Factions?
column9: Daniela Busse, Samuel Mann, Lisa Nathan, Chris Preist
column140: Sustainability; Interaction Design; Product Design
column141: This year’s Sustainability SIG invites participants to apply the conference theme “changing perspectives” to sustainability research and practice within the human computer interaction community. As the number of sustainability-oriented endeavors in the field continues to grow, so does the number of critiques on the work undertaken. Perspectives continue to shift concerning how the HCI community “should” attend to the monumental ecosystem changes societies face in the coming decades. For such an enormous problem, is it best to concentrate our limited resources (time, money, people) on compatible approaches in order to build on each other’s findings? Do recent critiques risk sundering a nascent community of scholars? Or is it misguided to privilege a limited number of approaches to addressing a complex, problematic situation?

column3: Consumer Engagement in Health Technologies Special Interest Group
column9: Karen Cheng, Kelly Caine, Wanda Pratt, Kay Connelly
column44: Department of Biomedical Informatics and Medical Education
column140: Health Care; Computer Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW); User-Centered Design / Human-Centered Design
column141: How do we keep consumers engaged in using health technologies?  We welcome all researchers and practitioners who are interested in this question to join us for a spirited discussion, hosted by the CHI Health Community.
